title: Why is measles so contagious?

options.label: B

options.text: They can absorb oxygen from the water

title: Are pandas the most misunderstood animal? - Lucy Cooke

multiple-choice.question: What event at the Chicago Zoo in the late 1930s led to the acquisition of a new panda, Mei Mei, and a prospective suitor, Mei Lan?

options.label: A
options.text: The birth of a new panda cub

options.label: B
options.text: The death of a media darling panda named Su-Lin

options.label: C
options.text: The introduction of a new panda enclosure

options.label: D
options.text: The arrival of a panda expert from China

multiple-choice.question: Why were Mei Mei and Mei Lan unable to produce offspring at the Chicago Zoo?

options.label: A
options.text: Mei Mei was too old to breed

options.label: B
options.text: Mei Lan was too young to breed

multiple-choice.question: What is a common misconception about pandas that has been perpetuated by humans?

options.label: D
options.text: They are native to North America

multiple-choice.question: Why is it challenging for zookeepers to determine the sex of a panda?

options.label: B
options.text: Pandas' external genitals appear late and are similar in both sexes

options.label: C
options.text: Pandas are born with clear sex-specific characteristics

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique challenge in breeding pandas due to the female's reproductive cycle?

options.label: A
options.text: Females can only be impregnated during a specific season

options.label: B
options.text: Females have a long gestation period

options.label: C
options.text: Females can only be impregnated 1 to 3 days each year

options.label: D
options.text: Females can become pregnant at any time

multiple-choice.question: How do female pandas in the wild signal their readiness to mate?

options.label: B
options.text: By rubbing their anal glands on tree trunks

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique behavior exhibited by male pandas during mating competitions?

options.label: C
options.text: They compete to see who can pee the highest

options.label: D
options.text: They release a specific scent to attract females

multiple-choice.question: Why are panda populations not booming despite the potency of panda sperm?

options.label: A
options.text: Females' short ovulation cycles and ability to reabsorb fetuses

options.label: B
options.text: Males' lack of interest in mating

options.label: C
options.text: The limited availability of food in the wild

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of climate change on panda habitats

multiple-choice.question: What is the most reliable approach to breeding pandas in captivity?

options.label: A
options.text: Showing young pandas footage of mating elders

options.label: D
options.text: Providing pandas with a naturalistic enclosure

multiple-choice.question: What is an alternative approach to conservation efforts that the author suggests?

options.label: A
options.text: Focusing on breeding pandas in captivity

options.label: D
options.text: Conducting further research on panda behavior

title: The unbelievable science of how we read

multiple-choice.question: What is the trick being played on readers every time they read something?

options.label: A
options.text: Letters are actually different sizes, even when they appear the same size.

options.label: B
options.text: Words are actually read from right to left.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain doesn't actually process words, it just guesses.

options.label: D
options.text: Reading is a completely conscious process.

multiple-choice.question: Why do letters with rounded tops have to be slightly taller than letters with flat tops?

options.label: A
options.text: So they can be read more easily.

options.label: B
options.text: So they appear the same size.

options.label: C
options.text: So they can be written more quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: So they can be typed more efficiently.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the illusion that makes lines appear longer or shorter than they actually are?
What is the theory that explains how our brains are able to read, even though we didn't evolve to do so?
What is the "shape alphabet" that our brains use to decode visual scenes?

options.label: A
options.text: A set of simple shapes, such as lines and curves.

options.label: B
options.text: A set of complex shapes, such as letters and numbers.

options.label: C
options.text: A set of abstract shapes, such as patterns and textures.

options.label: D
options.text: A set of geometric shapes, such as triangles and circles.

multiple-choice.question: How do our brains process words when we read?

options.label: A
options.text: By sounding out the individual letters.

options.label: B
options.text: By recognizing the shape of the word.

options.label: C
options.text: By directly turning the printed symbols into meaning.

options.label: D
options.text: By scanning the page from left to right.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "Word Superiority Effect"?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to recognize words more accurately than individual letters.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to recognize individual letters more accurately than words.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to read words more quickly than individual letters.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to read individual letters more quickly than words.

multiple-choice.question: How do our eyes move when we read?

options.label: A
options.text: Smoothly across the page from left to right.

options.label: B
options.text: In a zig-zag pattern across the page.

options.label: C
options.text: In small jumps, called saccades, from one word to the next.

options.label: D
options.text: In a circular motion, from the top of the page to the bottom.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the fovea, parafovea, and peripheral vision when we read?

options.label: B
options.text: To recognize the shape of words.

options.label: C
options.text: To gather information from different parts of the visual field.

options.label: D
options.text: To scan the page from left to right.

multiple-choice.question: How do we recognize words when we read?

options.label: A
options.text: By scanning the letters from left to right.

options.label: B
options.text: By recognizing the shape of the word.

options.label: C
options.text: By simultaneously comparing each letter position with those in all the words we've seen before.

options.label: D
options.text: By sounding out the individual letters.

title: Why is Texas hold 'em so popular? - James McManus

multiple-choice.question: In the 1800s, what was often at stake when cowboys played cards in saloons across the West?

options.label: B
options.text: A mountain of chips worth their weight in gold

multiple-choice.question: What two games ruled the card tables in New Orleans around 1800 and influenced the development of poker?

options.label: C
options.text: Players could discard and draw new cards

options.label: D
options.text: Players could only bet once per hand

multiple-choice.question: What event contributed to the rapid spread of poker throughout the United States?

options.label: D
options.text: The construction of the transcontinental railroad

multiple-choice.question: By what year had poker become popular in every state and territory in the United States?
What was a common method used by cheaters to gain an advantage in poker games?

options.label: A
options.text: Sneaking a cold deck into the game

options.label: B
options.text: Using a hidden earpiece to receive advice

options.label: C
options.text: Creating a distraction to steal chips

multiple-choice.question: What variant of poker became popular in the American West during the Gold Rush era?
Why was Texas Hold'em developed, and what feature made it a favorite among players?

options.label: A
options.text: It was developed to reduce cheating, and its low ratio of private to shared cards allowed for more deductions and tactical maneuvering.

options.label: B
options.text: It was developed to increase betting limits, and its high ratio of private to shared cards made it more exciting.

options.label: C
options.text: It was developed to accommodate more players, and its low ratio of private to shared cards allowed for more deductions and tactical maneuvering.

options.label: D
options.text: It was developed to simplify the game, and its lack of shared cards made it more accessible to beginners.

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with developing the mathematical foundation for game theory, which has applications in poker, economics, and military strategy?
What is the name of the annual tournament that attracts poker players from over a hundred countries?

title: The science of laughter - Sasha Winkler

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the abdominal muscles when a person laughs?

options.label: A
options.text: They relax and become less tense.

multiple-choice.question: According to researchers, which animals were found to be "basically giggling" while being tickled?
What is one possible reason why laughter may have originally developed, according to scientists?

options.label: B
options.text: To clearly signal friendly, non-aggressive intent.

multiple-choice.question: Why do scientists think laughter became contagious in humans?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's a way to show off intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's a way to express aggression.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's like an invitation to share in someone's emotional state.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's a way to assert dominance.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the brain when a person hears clips of laughter?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes less active and relaxed.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes more aggressive and dominant.

options.label: C
options.text: It activates key regions, triggering a smile or laugh.

multiple-choice.question: How does the presence of another person affect laughter, according to one study?

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases the frequency and duration of laughter.

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on laughter.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the frequency and duration of laughter.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes laughter more fake and insincere.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to distinguish between real and fake laughter, according to studies?

options.label: A
options.text: By looking at the person's facial expression.

options.label: B
options.text: By listening to the sound of the laughter.

options.label: C
options.text: By observing the person's body language.

options.label: D
options.text: By asking the person if they're laughing sincerely.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the brain's neurotransmitters and stress hormones when a person laughs?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain releases more stress hormones and fewer neurotransmitters.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain releases fewer stress hormones and more neurotransmitters.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain releases the same amount of stress hormones and neurotransmitters.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain becomes unaffected and neutral.

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential benefit of laughter, according to research?

options.label: A
options.text: It can increase stress and anxiety.

multiple-choice.question: At what age can babies start laughing, according to the transcript?

title: Does planting trees actually cool the planet? - Carolyn Beans

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of planting trees in the fight to curb climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: To absorb oxygen from the atmosphere

options.label: B
options.text: To absorb CO2 from the atmosphere

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the number of trees

options.label: B
options.text: Land twice the size of the UK

options.label: C
options.text: Land three times the size of the UK

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: How many times better are natural forests at carbon storage than plantations, according to one study?

Why can gains in carbon storage from plantation trees quickly be lost?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not native to the area

multiple-choice.question: What type of land is most targeted for a tree planting initiative in Africa, and what is the potential consequence of planting trees there?

options.label: A
options.text: Savannas, and it threatens wildlife that thrive in sunlight and open spaces

options.label: B
options.text: Deserts, and it helps to reduce carbon emissions

options.label: D
options.text: Mountains, and it reduces the risk of wildfires

options.label: B
options.text: Protecting forests and letting nature do the work

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How to clear icy roads, with science

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary issue with using salt to de-ice roads?

options.label: A
options.text: It's expensive to purchase and apply.

options.label: B
options.text: It's toxic for plants, wildlife, and freshwater ecosystems.

options.label: C
options.text: It's not effective at low temperatures.

options.label: D
options.text: It's difficult to obtain in large quantities.

multiple-choice.question: What scientific principle allows salt to lower the freezing point of water?
What is the main difference between sodium chloride and magnesium chloride/calcium chloride in terms of de-icing?

options.label: B
options.text: Magnesium chloride and calcium chloride are more corrosive.

options.label: C
options.text: Magnesium chloride and calcium chloride lower the freezing point more effectively.

options.label: D
options.text: Sodium chloride is more environmentally friendly.

multiple-choice.question: Why are some alternative salts, like magnesium chloride, considered better for the environment?

options.label: A
options.text: They're more expensive, so less is used.

options.label: C
options.text: Less is required in solution to achieve the same freezing point depression.

options.label: D
options.text: They're more effective at low temperatures.

multiple-choice.question: What is one downside of using magnesium chloride salts for de-icing?

options.label: A
options.text: They're more expensive than sodium chloride.

options.label: B
options.text: They're still somewhat corrosive to cars.

options.label: C
options.text: They're less effective at low temperatures.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an eco-friendly alternative to salt for de-icing roads?
What is a potential issue with using byproducts from vodka distilleries or sugar beet processing facilities for de-icing?

options.label: B
options.text: They're not effective at low temperatures.

multiple-choice.question: What is a downside of using urea as an eco-friendly solution to road salt?

options.label: A
options.text: It's not effective at low temperatures.

options.label: C
options.text: It decreases dissolved oxygen and causes algal blooms in waterways.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of brining roads with liquid salt solution?

options.label: A
options.text: To de-ice roads after snow or ice has formed.

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent ice from forming on the road in the first place.

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the amount of salt used for de-icing.

multiple-choice.question: What is a reported benefit of brining roads?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces the overall cost of maintaining winter roads.

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the amount of salt used for de-icing.

options.label: C
options.text: It's more effective at low temperatures.

title: What the biggest brain on Earth can do - David Gruber and Shane Gero

multiple-choice.question: What percentage drop in successful strikes did whalers experience within a few years of operating in the North Pacific?

multiple-choice.question: What is the suspected method by which sperm whales were able to adapt to the presence of whaling ships?

options.text: They broadcast survival strategies to each other

options.text: They became more aggressive towards whalers

options.label: C
